abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of this project is
            rated as marginally to moderately satisfactory. Major
            lessons learned from the project are: 1) Government policy
            on institutional reform and restructuring of the
            agricultural services should have been clarified early.
            Uncertainty over conditions of service and fear of
            redundancy were genuine concerns of staff, which slowed down
            the reform process. 2) Key issues should be addressed
            upfront rather than during project implementation. 3) A
            legal framework for Agricultural Research and Extension Unit
            should have been in place at the beginning of the project.
            4) Setting up Directorate of Agricultural Research and
            Extension (DARE) as just another unit under the Ministry was
            not the best arrangement. It would have been preferable to
            establish DARE as an independent unit right from the start
            and recruit staff outside of the Ministry. 5) A more
            pro-active role of the Bank would have been needed to
            address the problem of poor project implementation in the
            early years of the project. 6) System modernization from
            surface to drip irrigation has contributed to substantial
            savings in water use and greater profitability through
            improved distribution efficiency. 7) The financial
            participation of planters in the Western Coast Pilot Project
            has instilled sense of planter ownership of the project and
            contributed to its sustainability.
